sourceString: The younger patients, in many practices younger than 14 years, and in nearly all for children younger than 8 years will require pediatric serology surveillance.
targetString: Bato ya maladi oyo baza bilenge, mbala mingi bazalaki na nse ya mibu 14, mpe na bana nyonso oyo bakokisaki nanu te mibu 8, ekosenga bokengeli ya serologie mpo na bana.

sourceString: We will develop a new request form for practices to capture recent travel and exposure to COVID-19.
targetString: Tokosala formilere ya sika ya bosengi mpo na koyeba bisika ya sika oyo moto akendaki mobembo mpe soki akutanaki na moto to bato ya COVID-19.

sourceString: We will pilot a scheme for collecting convalescent serology from people with confirmed cases and who have had an acute virology sample at the time of their infection.
targetString: Tokokamba misala ya kosangisa serologie ya bato bazobika na bato oyo babelaki mpenza mpe oyo bazwaki bango echantillon ya virisi ya makasi na ntango bazalaka kobela.

sourceString: This is to identify a carrier state in patients who have recovered from the virus but may continue shedding the virus.
targetString: Eza mpo na koyeba lolenge virisi yango eza na bato oyo basi babika na virisi wana kasi bakoki kolanda kopanza yango.

sourceString: If there are a small number of cases, this may assist in developing a test kit for patients to take to their own GP and explore its acceptability to patients.
targetString: Soki motango ya bato eza moke mpenza, ekoki kosalisa na kosala eloko ya kosalela ekzame mpo bato ya maladi basala GP na bango bango moko mpe kotala soki bato ya maladi bakoki kozwa yango.

sourceString: If there are a large number of COVID-19 cases nationally, convalescent samples could be collected from RCGP RSC practices where there are confirmed cases, with the ability to link to the full medical record.
targetString: Soki bato oyo bazobela COVID-19 baza mingi na mokili moko, bakoki kozwa ba echantillon ya bato bazobika na RCGP RSC esika baza na bankombo ya bato oyo baza na yango mpenza, mpe baza na makoki ya kotala dosie mobimba ya makambo ya monganga.

sourceString: This process may include checking pseudonymized NHS numbers for positive individuals at RCGP RSC practices, checking current PHE guidance regarding considerations of infectiousness for confirmed cases, and offering the patient an appointment following the previously mentioned process.
targetString: Ekoki kosenga kotalela motango ya NHS mpo na bato oyo bakanga maladi epai ya lisanga RCGP RSC, kotalela litambwisi ya sika ya PHE na oyo etali kotalela bato oyo baza mpenza na maladi, mpe kopesa bato ya maladi rendez-vous na kolanda metode tolobeli likolo.

sourceString: This needs to be carefully coordinated nationally across the network and may require PHE to ensure individuals are not contacted by multiple agencies.
targetString: Esengeli balandela yango malamu na mboka mobimba na nzela ya resaux mpe ekoki kosenga ete PHE etalela soki masanga mingi ezoluka te kokutana na bato.

sourceString: RCGP RSC could provide a useful structure to channel the initial contact once PHE has made a request.
targetString: RCGP RSC ekoki kobimisa mwango mpo na kolandela bokutani ya liboso nsima ya lisengi ya PHE.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of a LRTI.
targetString: Bato ya RCGP RSC oyo basanganaka na bokengeli ya mbula na mbula ya virisi ya grippe babandi kozwa ba echantillon ya bato ya maladi oyo baza na bilembo ya LRTI.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Ba echantillon nyonso oyo tozwaki bazosala yango ekzame mpo na koyeba soki eza na grippe mpe COVID-19.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC will explore ways to collect convalescent samples from any patients tested positive for COVID-19 through the extension of the virological surveillance.
targetString: RCGP RSC ekoluka lolenge ya kosangisa ba echantillon ya bato oyo baza na kobika ya bato nyonso oyo bakangaki maladi ya COVID-19 na nzela ya bokengeli ya molai ya virisi.

sourceString: From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.
targetString: Banda na ebandeli, tokotalela malamu bansango mpo na koyeba soki ekosalisa mpenza na bolukiluki na mikolo ezoya.

sourceString: Our clinical data will be linked to virology.
targetString: Bansango oyo toza na yango toko lier yango na virologie.

sourceString: We will curate our data using the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles.
targetString: Tokobongisa bansango na biso na kolanda mitinda ekoki kozwama, ekoki komonana, ekoki kokabolama, ekoki kosalelama.

sourceString: To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.
targetString: Mpo na kolembisa mosala, totye bansango elongo na bansango ya bolukiluki ya kolongono ya nzoto ya Royaume-Uni mpe resaux ya bilembetli ya bansango ya kolongono ya nzoto ya Eropa.

sourceString: The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.
targetString: Metode oyo ya kozwa bansango esimbami na mayele ya kolandela kopanzana ya maladi, esika oyo babengaka intervention nonpharmaceutique (NPIs) esalelamaka mpo na kobundisa maladi mabe ya mbalakaka na likanisi ya kosilisa yango.

sourceString: This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.
targetString: Mokano ya mayele oyo eza ya kokitisa taux na kati ya bato mpe kosala ete virisi epanzana mingi.

sourceString: To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.
targetString: Mpo na kosalela yango, guvernema ya Royaume-Uni emonisaki kala te mposa ya komeka mayele ya kosalisa bato bamifandela.

sourceString: By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.
targetString: Na kolandelaka motango ya kobotama (R) (moyene ya bato oyo bazozwa maladi mpe kopesa yango na bato mosusu) mpe koluka kokitisa R na nse ya 1, mayele oyo ezoluka kokitisa motango na nse ya banivo to (ndenge tomonaki na virisi ya sika ya maladi makasi ya mpema mpe Ebola) mpo na kokanga nzela ete bato bapesa yango te na bato mosusu.

sourceString: As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.
targetString: Ndenge makambo esalemaki na maladi ya 2009 H1N1 emonisi yango, NPIs ekoki kosalisa mingi na kolembisa maladi mabe.

sourceString: Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.
targetString: Eloko ekosalisa biso mingi na bolukiluki oyo eza ntango oyo bato mingi mpenza bakozwa maladi mpe kokoba kolandela yango na kozwaka bansango mpe kolandela bokoli na yango mpe ntango mosusu oyo bato mingi mpenza bakozwa yango na ntango tozolongola mibeko ya komifandela.

sourceString: There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.
targetString: Mikanda mingi esi ebimi oyo ezolobela ntina ya kotya mibeko kokanga virisi nzela na oyo etali kobima ya COVID-19 mokili Chine.

sourceString: A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.
targetString: Mwango mosusu ya ntina mpo na kobundisa maladi mabe eza eleko oyo moto azwaka virisi kino ntango oyo moto yango akomaka na likoko ya kopesa yandi na basusu mpe eleko oyo azalaka kaka na likoki ya kopesa basusu.

sourceString: These factors, if estimated accurately, will give good predictions for the likely length of the pandemic, the final number of infected cases.
targetString: Makambo oyo, soki totaleli yango malamumalamu, ekosalisa na koyeba malamu ntango oyo maladi mabe ekoumela, motango ya nsuka ya bato oyo bazwi maladi yango.

sourceString: We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.
targetString: Toza na likanisi ya kosalela bosukisi ya Bayesian (ABC) na (mbala mosusu bokeseni ya monene) Oyo bakoki kozwa yango -Oyo bakutanaki na bato baza na yango- Oyo bazwi maladi-Oyo balongoli yango (SEIR) lolenge ya kolandela maladi oyo eyebani mpenza te.

sourceString: Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
targetString: Mayele ya boye ekoki kosalisa na kosala bokokanisi mpe basi basalela yango na ba domaine mingi ata mpe na koyeba ndenge maladi elongwaka na moto moko mpe epesamaka na moto mosusu.

sourceString: They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
targetString: Ebongi mpenza na ntango oyo mosala na yango ezala te mpe ezosenga kosalela mayele ya kala na ndakisa na Markov chain Monte Carlo.

sourceString: Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.
targetString: Emonana ete mayele ya boye esimbaka na bokengeli ya bansango ya ASPREN, reseaux moko oyo elandelaka GPs mpe ba-infirmier oyo basalaka rapore ya ba ILIS oyo bamoni mpe ya maladi mosusu, mpe kuna basi balonga kosilisa makambo neti kobungisa bansango mpe ntina ya kobongisa lolenge ya kosala botaleli.

sourceString: Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.
targetString: Lisusu, bametode ya kokabola esi eyeba ntango oyo bato mingi mpenza bazwaka maladi.

sourceString: Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.
targetString: Tokoki koyeba ba parametre ya lolenge ya SEIR na bansango ya mingi mpo na metode ya bokokanisi, mpe bametode oyo basi basalela yango na babiblioteke mingi ya R; toza na likanisi ya kosalela babiblioteke ABSEIR (oyo batyaka na GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) mpe bisaleli abc (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) mpo na kolandela mposa nyonso mibeko batye mpo na kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te.

sourceString: Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.
targetString: Banda tosalelala modele ya SIR ya maladi mabe na kolanda ABC, tozokanisa ete ekosalisa mpo bansango ya sika oyo tokozwa mposo nyonso ezala moke mpenza.

sourceString: For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.
targetString: Na ndakisa, tala metode ABC oyo basalelaki na bansango ya maladi ya malili ebengami Tristan da Cunha ya mobu 1967, esika motango I (motango ya bato bazwi maladi wana) mpe R (motango ya bato oyo babiki) eza mbala mingi bazomi.

sourceString: Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.
targetString: Na nsuka, longola metode touti kolobela, tokosalela metode ya Kaplan-Meier na ba résultat mibale (bato bakufi mpe bato babiki) mpo na koyeba taux ya liwa.

sourceString: This approach is independent of the ABC methodology and will allow comparisons between estimates from the two modelling approaches to judge robustness of results.
targetString: Mayele oyo eza na boyokani te na metode ABC mpe ekosalisa na kosala bokesenisi na kati ya motango euti na bametode mibale ya koyeba bokasi ya ba résultat.

sourceString: RCGP RSC's surveillance with PHE is defined as Health Protection under Regulation 3 of The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
targetString: Bokengeli ya RCGP RSC elongo na PHE eza libateli ya kolongono ya nzoto na kolanda mobeko 3 ya misala ya kolongono ya nzoto (Kobatela bansango ya moto ya maladi) Mibeko ya 2002.

sourceString: This has been confirmed by PHE's Caldicott Guardian's Office.
targetString: Yango endimisama na biro ya PHE Caldicott Guardian.

sourceString: We do not see any increased risk to practices or practitioners taking part in this surveillance.
targetString: Tozomona te bokoli ata ya likama moko na ndenge minganga to ba infirmier ya sika bazosangana na bokengeli oyo.

sourceString: Infection prevention and control advice will follow extant national guidance.
targetString: Kokanga maladi nzela mpe batoli ya kobatela yango ekosalema na kolanda litambwisi ya mboka.

sourceString: Any cases identified will be managed according to the PHE/NHS guidance in force at the time, including advice for identified contacts.
targetString: Lokola tokolandela maladi nyonso oyo emonani na kolandela litambwisi ya PHE/NHS oyo tozosalela sikoyo, ata mpe batoli mpo na koyeba ndenge bato oyo bakutanaki.

sourceString: However, our training will include reminders about safe handling of specimens and revision of infection control measures anticipated to be high in our practices.
targetString: Kasi, formation na biso ekozala mpe na makundoli etali kosalela ba echantillon na bokengi mpe ete mwango ya kolandela maladi ezala likolo mingi epai ya minganga na biso.

sourceString: It is a key part of Regulation 12 about safe care and treatment, periodically inspected by the Care Quality Commission.
targetString: Eza eteni ya ntina ya Mobeko 12 oyo ezolobela kosalisa bato ya maladi na bokengi; balandelaka yango mbala na mbala na departema elandelaka makambo ya kosalisa bato ya maladi.

sourceString: Travel History and Clinical Descriptors of the COVID-19 Infections
targetString: Lisolo ya mobembo mpe ndenge ya kolimbola maladi ya COVID-19

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices have been advised on the clinical coding that has been made available for COVID-19 across all CMR systems.
targetString: Bayebisi bato ya RCGP RSC oyo bazosala bakode ya bansango ya bato ya maladi ete basi babimisi yango mpo na COVID-19 na ba systeme nyonso ya CMR.

sourceString: This includes information on coding of clinical descriptors (Table 4) and any recent travel history.
targetString: Etaleli mpe bansango ya kotya bakode na ba echantillon ya bato ya maladi (Tablo 4) mpe mobembo nyonso asalaki kala te.

sourceString: Establishment of Extended Virology Sampling
targetString: Kokomisa molai virologie ya ba echantillon

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of LRTI.
targetString: Bato ya RCGP RSC oyo basanganaka na bokengeli ya mbula na mbula ya virisi ya grippe, babandi kozwa ba echantillon ya bato ya maladi oyo baza na bilembo ya LRTI.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Ba echantillon nyonso oyo tozwaki bazosala yango ekzame mpo na koyeba soki eza na grippe mpe COVID-19.

sourceString: This has led to initial early identification of background spread in low-risk patients.
targetString: Yango esalisa na kobanda koyeba esika maladi ebandaki kokotela bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama mingi te.

sourceString: As of March 7, 2020, the surveillance system has detected 2 cases of COVID-19 in low-risk patients with no history of travel through extended virological sampling.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 7 sanza ya nsambo 2020, systeme ya bokengeli ekangaki bato 2 oyo bazalaki na COVID-19 oyo bazalaki na likama mingi mpe basala te mobembo mingi, tomonaka yango na nzela ya echantillon ya bato ya maladi.

sourceString: This protocol describes how we have adapted a national influenza surveillance system to monitor community spread of an unexpected infection of COVID-19.
targetString: Metode oyo ezolimbola ndenge tomesana na systeme ya bokengeli ya grippe mpo na kolandela kopanzana ya COVID-19 na ndenge eyebani te.

sourceString: We have rapidly created and incorporated new codes to allow data recording, and are collecting data to monitor the effectiveness of containment strategies.
targetString: Tosali na lombango mpe tokotisa bakode ya sika mpo esalisa biso na kokoma bansango, mpe tosangisaka bansango mpo na koyeba bokasi ya mibeko ezwami oyo ezosenga bato bamifandela.

sourceString: Through this surveillance, we intend to find out more about the epidemiology of COVID-19 in ambulatory care.
targetString: Na nzela ya bokengeli oyo, likanisi na biso eza ya koyeba makambo mingi etali maladi COVID-19 na esika ebengami soins ambulatoire.

sourceString: In particular, its rate of spread, both temporal and geographical.
targetString: Mingimingi, taux ya kopanzana na yango, na mokili mpe na bamboka.

sourceString: Our testing of low-risk patients will also inform whether the containment strategy that is based on virology testing of high-risk patients and their contacts plus self-isolation is effective.
targetString: Kosala baekzame na bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama mingi te eyebisaka mpe soki mayele ya kosenga bato bamifandela oyo esimbami na kosala ekzame na bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama ya makasi mpe bato bakutanaki na bango mpe ete komifandela ezobota mbuma.

sourceString: Containment should slow the spread, and there may be benefits in the management of spread from intense surveillance.
targetString: Komifandela esalaka ete epanzana mingi te, mpe bokengeli ya makasi ya kopanzana ya maladi ekoki kozala na matomba mingi.

sourceString: However, there may come a point at which the virus spreads more widely into the population, as has happened in Italy.
targetString: Kasi, ekoki kozala na ntango oyo virisi ezopanzana mingi na kati ya bato, ndenge esalemaki na Italie.

sourceString: Surveillance of low-risk patients should inform when we reach this tipping point and when infection rates start to remit.
targetString: Kokengela bato ya maladi oyo baza na likama mingi te esengeli koyebisa ntango tokomi na eleko oyo wana mpe ntango taux ya maladi ebandi kokita.

sourceString: The epidemiology of COVID-19 remains emergent.
targetString: Maladi ya COVID-19 eza kaka makasi.

sourceString: The registration-based nature of UK primary care means that we will be able to create a complete picture of the cumulative incidence and duration.
targetString: Ndenge bazokomisa bansango ya premiers soins na Royaume-Uni elimboli ete tokoyeba malamu motango nyonso ya bato oyo bazwi maladi mpe ntango oyo esali.

sourceString: The surveillance system should be able to identify areas where COVID-19 spread is taking place that might be suitable for trials of antiviral therapy.
targetString: Ebongiseli ya kokengela esengeli kokoka koyeba bisika oyo COVID-19 ezopanzana oyo ebongi mpo na komeka mangwele na yango na bato.

sourceString: We could also follow up on the effectiveness or any adverse reactions to these medicines or vaccinations.
targetString: Tokokí pe kolandela bolongi to bakpokoso ya mabe na bakisi yango to bamangwele yango.

sourceString: Finally, early detection of a confirmed COVID-19 case has exemplified the rapid implementation of this enhanced surveillance in the national network.
targetString: Na suka, boyebi na tango malamu ya bokono ya cas ya COVID-19 kati ya moto ekopesa ndakisa ya kosalela na bombango bokengeli emata na reseau ekolo mobimba.

sourceString: Safety of practices is our primary concern.
targetString: Bosembo ya bisaleli na biso totie liboso na motema.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC has operated for over 50 years and has been involved in collecting samples to monitor disease and vaccine effectiveness through the Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, and the 2009 Swine flu pandemic.
targetString: RCGP RSC ebanda misala koleka mibu 50 pe azali kati ya likambo ya bokongoli ya ba echantillon pona kenge bavaccin malamu penza tango ya pandemie ya grippe ya Hong Kong na1968/69, grippe ya Russe ya 1977/78, pe pandemie ya grippe ya ngulu na 2009.

sourceString: We are not aware of any increased risk to practice staff or other patients from involvement in surveillance.
targetString: Toyebi te likambo etali bobakisi ya likama na basali to bato ya bokono mosusu na bokotisi bango na bokengeli.

sourceString: Pandemic preparedness is part of the role of the RCGP RSC.
targetString: Komilengela pona pandemi ezali ndambo ya mosala ya RCGP RSC.

sourceString: It is plausible that enhanced coding of information from contacts with the practices in RCGP RSC will reduce the likelihood of people who may be suspected COVID-19 cases being brought to the surgery inadvertently.
targetString: Ezo monana na miso polele ete kocoder nsango na bokangani na bisaleli na RCGP RSC ekokitisa mabe na bato baye bakoki kokaniselama bazali na bokono ya COVID-19 bamemama na disuku ya bopasoli pona kozanga boyebi.

sourceString: Where cases are detected unexpectedly, it is probably helpful for that patient, their contacts, and the practice to know.
targetString: Bisika bacas ezomonana kozanga bozeli na yango, ekoki kozala na lisalisi pona mobeli wana, bacontacki naye, na esaleli bayeba.

sourceString: The impact on practices has been to close for a day, if a case is found, for deep cleaning and then reopen.
targetString: Kwokoso na esaleli ezalaki ete mokolo wana bakanga, soki cas emonani mpo basokola mozindo pe bafungola.

sourceString: The principal limitations of our system are the number of data points.
targetString: Ndelo monene na systemi nabiso nde eza lotango ya bapoint ya badonnee.

sourceString: We are collecting serology and virology data from 100 sites, which covers a small group of the population.
targetString: Tozo kongola badonnee ya serologie pe virologie epai ya basite 100, moto ezo talamela lotango moke ya bato.

sourceString: This has been satisfactory for monitoring influenza, but we are not certain if this is a sufficiently large sample for the COVID-19 outbreak.
targetString: Oyo ezalaki nango malamu pona kokengela ba grippe kasi nde ezangi bosolo ya makasi soki monene nango ekoka penza na echantillon pona bobimi ya COVID-19.

sourceString: Our sites (surveillance practices) are currently fixed, and it could be helpful to be able to rapidly onboard practices in regions where there are more cases.
targetString: Site nabiso (bisaleli ya bokengeli) ezali sik'oyo fixe, pe ekoki kozala likambo ya ntina monene ematisa masalisi na bombango na bingunda bacas mingi koleka ezali.

sourceString: Currently, we will be reporting weekly.
targetString: Mikol'oyo to kobanda koraporter poso na poso.

sourceString: Our existing system can be enhanced to twice weekly, but maybe daily or hourly data should be our current approach.
targetString: Systeme nabiso eko kobakisama na bolamu mpo ezala mbala mibale na mposo, kasi mbala mosusu ya mokolo to ya ngonga esengeli ezala nzela nabiso ya sik'oyo.

sourceString: Opportunistic sampling for serology in children younger than 10 years might be limited due to the overall reduced rate of blood tests in children.
targetString: Echantillonage ya opportunite pona serologie na bana bilenge nase ya mibu 10 ekoki kozala na ndelo mpona boyekoli ya makila ya bana eza moke.

sourceString: The extended surveillance using the RCGP RSC-PHE network for the emergent COVID-19 outbreak has been established rapidly.
targetString: Bobakisi ya bokengeli na bosaleli ya reseau ya RCGP RSC-PHE mpona bobimi ya COVID-19 esi ebelemi na bombango penza.

sourceString: The model of getting the appropriate informatics to enable capture of the required data has already been a success, with data recording starting the week the codes were created.
targetString: Modele ya bozwi bainformatiki elongobani mpo esalisa na kocapter badonnee esengami esi elongi, bongo nde bokomi ya badonnee ebandaki mokolo ya mposo bacode ebongisamaki.

sourceString: In addition, modifying the existing surveillance system to collect population data in a parallel way has also been effective.
targetString: Na kobakisa, bokesenesi ya systeme ya bokengeli oyo esi esalama pona kokongola badonnee ya bato na nzela ya paralleli ezalaki pe na bolongi.

sourceString: However, we are at present unsure as to whether the scale of this surveillance provides sufficient data to drive local containment strategies or if reporting infrequently meets the need of our information age.
targetString: Kasi nde pona sik'oyo tozo yeba penza te soki to longola kaka bokengeli yango pona kopesa badonnee ekoka pona kobatela bastrategie ya confinement ya esika to kosala reportage ezo silisa posa ya koyeba nsango ya sik'oyo.

sourceString: National Basketball Association suspends season due to COVID-19 concerns
targetString: Association national ya Basket esukisaki mpona likama ya COVID-19.

sourceString: On Wednesday, the United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) suspended its professional basketball season due to concerns regarding COVID-19.
targetString: Na mokolo ya misato, Ekipi ya Basket ya Etats Unis (NBA) esukisaki saison mpona COVID-19.

sourceString: The NBA's decision followed a Utah Jazz player testing positive for the COVID-19 virus.
targetString: Ekateli ya NBA ebandaki tango joeur ya Jazz na Utah abelaki na virisi COVID-19.

sourceString: The NBA did not release the identity of the player in question in its announcement.
targetString: NBA epesaki nkombo ya joeur ten a basango na bango.

sourceString: They did say he was not present at Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, where the Utah Jazz were to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.
targetString: Balobaki te soki ye azalaki na Chesapeake Energie na Arena ya egumba ya Oklahoma, esika oyo bajoueur ya Utah Jazz balingaki babeta na baThunder ya egumba ya Oklahoma.

sourceString: According to its press release, the NBA was "suspending game play following the conclusion of [Wednesday's] schedule of games until further notice."
targetString: Kati na basango na bango, NBA ‘'esukisaki bajeux nsima ya kosilisa Masano (ya mokolo ya misato)''

sourceString: The Jazz's game was cancelled, as was another NBA game Wednesday between the Sacramento Kings and the New Orleans Pelicans.
targetString: Masano ya Jazz ekangaki, mpe mosusu ya NBA na mokolo ya misato kati na Sacramento Kings na baPelicans ya New Orleans.

sourceString: Other games scheduled for Wednesday were still held, according to NBC News.
targetString: Masano oyo esengelaki ebetama na mokolo ya misato ebetamaki, ndenge Basango ya NBC elobaki.

sourceString: The United States' other major basketball organization, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which runs college basketball, has cancelled its own tournament, March Madness, for both men's and women's leagues.
targetString: Organisation monene ya Etats Unis ya basket, Association ya ba athlete ya college, ekangi masano, Liboma ya Mars, mpona masano ya mibale mpe ya basi.

sourceString: According to Johns Hopkins University, as of Wednesday, there were at least 1,279 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the United States.
targetString: Mpona universite ya John Hopkins, na mokolo ya misato, bazalaki na bato ya kobela na COVID-19 1,279 na Etats Unis.

sourceString: CNBC reported there were at least 118,381 cases worldwide.
targetString: CNBC elobaki ete bazali 118,381 na mokili nyonso.

sourceString: US President Trump declares COVID-19 national emergency
targetString: Mokambi ya US Trump abengaki COVID-19 likama national

sourceString: On Friday, United States President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.
targetString: Na mokolo ya mitano, Mokambi ya Etats Unis Donald Trump abengaki likambo ya kopalangana coronavirisi likama national.

sourceString: The move came two days after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak, which causes the COVID-19 disease, to be a pandemic.
targetString: Ezalaki mikolo mibale nsima ya Organisation Mondial ya Sante abenga yango Likama, oyo esali ete maladi ya COVID-19 ezala pandemi.

sourceString: The move gives the federal government access to around US$50 billion in extra funding to combat the pandemic, according to NBC News.
targetString: Epesi gouvernema federal babimisa US$50 bilio ya mbogo ya kobomba mpona kobunda pandemic, elobi basango ya NBC News.

sourceString: The proclamation specifically said "the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States constitutes a national emergency" and said the national emergency began on March 1, almost two weeks before the proclamation itself.
targetString: Na monoko na bango moko balobaki ‘'Kopalangana ya COVID-19 na Etats Unis ezali Likama national'' mpe balobi ete likama national ebandaki sanza ya misato mokolo ya 1, mposo mibale liboso ya kopesa yango nkombo.

sourceString: The United States Department of Health and Human Services declared the outbreak a "public health emergency" on January 31.
targetString: Departema ys Etats Unis mpona Kolongono mpe kosalisa bato ebengaki yango kopalangana ya likama ya kolongono ya bato'' sanza ya liboso mokolo ya 31.

sourceString: Trump did not place the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in charge of the government's response to COVID-19, which Politico reported left some experts in disaster management disappointed.
targetString: Trump apesi nguya te na Federation ya Kolandela Likama (FEMA) mpona kolandela mosala ya gouvernema na etumba ya COVID-19, oyo Politico alobaki etikaki bayeko mingi na kati ya kobunga.

sourceString: Politico quoted Tim Manning, formerly a deputy administrator at FEMA, as saying "FEMA has an important role in coordinating the larger response to the crisis" and "[i]f there's an emergency, FEMA needs to be involved."
targetString: Politico alobaki nini Tim Manning alobaki, oyo azalaki depute ya FEMA ya kala, alobi ‘FEMA ezali na mosala ya ntina na kolanda mosala ya etumba oyo'' mpe ‘'Soki likama ezali esengeli ete FEMA ayeba.''

sourceString: Trump made the decision under provisions of the National Emergencies Act, amongst other governing authorities.
targetString: Trump akatelaki na kati na Act ya Likama National, mpe kati ya mibeko misusu.

sourceString: The Trump administration also announced other efforts in response to COVID-19, including waiving the interest it collects on federal student loans and increasing U.S. strategic oil reserve oil purchases.
targetString: Biro ya Trump ebandaki misala misusu mpe mpona kobundela COVID-19, lokola kolandela banyongo ya bana kelasi mpe komatisa mafuta ya ekolo ya U.S.

sourceString: Impact of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic on education
targetString: Bopusi ya maladi mabe coronavirisi 2019–20 na kelasi

sourceString: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic has affected educational systems worldwide, leading to the widespread closures of schools and universities.
targetString: Coronavirisi 2019–20 ebebisi mabongisi ya mateya na mokili mobimba, esali ete biteyelo mpe ba iniversite ekangama.

sourceString: As of 8 April 2020, approximately 1.716 billion learners have been affected due to school closures in response to COVID-19.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 8 sanza ya minei 2020, bana kelasi pene ya bamilliard 1,716 bazwa mpasi mpo na bokangami ya biteyelo mpo na kobundisa COVID-19.

sourceString: According to UNESCO monitoring, 188 countries have implemented nationwide closures and 5 have implemented local closures, impacting about 99.4%  of the world's student population.
targetString: Na kolanda botaleli ya UNESCO, mikili 188 bakangi bakelasi na mboka na bango mobimba mpe bokangami ya ekolo mobimba mpe mikili 5 ekangi biteyelo ndambu, yango epesi mpasi na bana ya kelasi pene ya 99,4% na mokili mobimba.

sourceString: On 23 March 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) released a statement announcing the cancellation of Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U examinations for the May/June 2020 series across all countries.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 23 sanza ya misato 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) abimisaki maloba etatolaki ete ba annulaki Cambridge IGCSE, Niveau O ya Cambridge, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Dipolme ya Cambridge AICE , mpe ba Pre-U ekzame ya Cambridge mpo na sanza ya mitano/motoba 2020 na mikili nyonso.

sourceString: International Baccalaureate exams have also been cancelled.School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families, but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences.
targetString: Ekzame baccalaureat Internationale ezalaki mpe annule. Bokangami ya biteyelo epesi mpasi kaka te na bana ya kelasi, bateyi mpe mabota, kasi mpe na nkita mpe mokili mobimba.

sourceString: School closures in response to COVID-19 have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services.
targetString: Bokangami ya biteyelo mpo na COVID-19 ebimisi na mpwasa makambo mosusu ya bomoi mpe ya nkita, ata mpe banyongo ya bana ya kelasi, boyekoli ya digitali, kozanga bilei, kozanga esika ya kofanda, mpe kozanga misala neti esika ya kobatela bana, kolongono ya nzoto, bandako, internet, mpe misala ya kosalisa bibosono.

sourceString: The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who could not work.In response to school closures, UNESCO recommended the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.
targetString: Bopusi na yango ezalaki makasi mingi na bana ya babola mpe na mabota na bango, esalaki ete kelasi ekatana, bana bazanga bilei, mpe mpasi ya mbongo mpo na mabota oyo bazali na mosala te. Nsima ya kokangama ya bakelasi, UNESCO elendisaki kosalela manaka ya koteya ya mosika mpe kosala ba-application mpe bisika mpo biteyelo mpe balakisi bakutana na bana kelasi na mosika mpe ebebisa mingi te programe ya koteya bato.

sourceString: Efforts to stem the spread of COVID-19 through non-pharmaceutical interventions and preventive measures such as social-distancing and self-isolation have prompted the widespread closure of primary, secondary, and tertiary schooling in over 100 countries.Previous outbreaks of infectious diseases have prompted widespread school closings around the world, with varying levels of effectiveness.
targetString: Bokasi ya kokata bopalangani ya bokono ya COVID-19 na bosaleli ya bamezile ya banzela ya bankisi te lokola bokaboli bato na bobombami bwa bato moko-moko eye kobanda bokanga bipai bianso ya biteyelo ya yambo, ya mibale, na ya misato na mikolo mboka toloba koleka 100. Bokono ya bokabwani na lombango ya liboso etindaki bokangami ya biteyelo na mokili mobimba kasi degre ya bolamu na yango ekesanaki.

sourceString: Mathematical modelling has shown that transmission of an outbreak may be delayed by closing schools.
targetString: Bamodele ya mathematiki elakisi ete bokabola ya bokono ekokokangama kamwa na bokangi ya biteyelo.

sourceString: However, effectiveness depends on the contacts children maintain outside of school.
targetString: Kasi nde, bolamu na yango eyebanaka na bobelemi ya bokangani ya bana na bato ya libanda ya biteyelo.

sourceString: School closures may be effective when enacted promptly.
targetString: Bokangami ya biteyelo ebongisaka makambo soki esalami noki-noki.

sourceString: If school closures occur late relative to an outbreak, they are less effective and may not have any impact at all.
targetString: Soki bakangi biteyelo mikolo mingi nsima ya kobima ya maladi, esalisaka mpenza te mpe mbala mosusu ekozala na bopusi moko te.

sourceString: Additionally, in some cases, the reopening of schools after a period of closure has resulted in increased infection rates.
targetString: Lisusu, ntango mosusu, kofungwama ya biteyelo nsima ya eleko ya kokanga yango esala ete taux ya kopanzana ya maladi emata.

sourceString: As closures tend to occur concurrently with other interventions such as public gathering bans, it can be difficult to measure the specific impact of school closures.During the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic in the United States, school closures and public gathering bans were associated with lower total mortality rates.
targetString: Lokola bokangami eyaka mingi-mingi elongo na ba intervention mosusu, ndakisa bopekisi ya bokutani ya bato ebele, ekozala mpasi mingi mpo na koyeba mambi matali bokangami ya biteyelo. Na maladi ya grippe ya 1918-1919 na ekolo ya États-Unis, bokangami ya biteyelo na bosangani ya bato esalaki ete bato bakufi mingi te.

sourceString: Cities that implemented such interventions earlier had greater delays in reaching peak mortality rates.
targetString: Bingumba oyo esalelaki ba intervention ya lolenge wana liboso bawumelaki mpo bazwa motango ya likolo na liwa ya bato.

sourceString: Schools closed for a median duration of 4 weeks according to a study of 43 US cities' response to the Spanish Flu.
targetString: Biteyelo ekangamaki na moyenne bamposo 4 na bolandi boyekoli ya bingumba 43 ya États-Unis nsima ya kobima ya grippe ya Espaniole.

sourceString: School closures were shown to reduce morbidity from the Asian flu by 90% during the 1957–58 outbreak, and up to 50% in controlling influenza in the US, 2004–2008.Multiple countries successfully slowed the spread of infection through school closures during the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: Emonani ete bokangami ya biteyelo ekitisaki motango ya bato oyo bakufaki na Asie na grippe 90% na kobima na yango ya 1957-58, mpe emataki kino na 50% mpo bamibatelaki na grippe na États-Unis, na 2004–2008. Mikili ebele elongaki kokitisa bopalangani ya bokono na bokangami ya biteyelo na mbula ya maladi ya grippe ya H1N1 2009.

sourceString: School closures in the city of Oita, Japan, were found to have successfully decreased the number of infected students at the peak of infection; however closing schools was not found to have significantly decreased the total number of infected students.
targetString: Bokangi ya biteyelo na engumba Oita, Japon, emonanaki ete ekitisaka mingi mpenza motango ya bana oyo bazwaki maladi wana ntango ekomaki makasi mingi; kasi bokangi ya biteyelo ekitisaki mpenza te motango ya bana banso ya kelasi bazwaki maladi yango.

sourceString: Mandatory school closures and other social distancing measures were associated with a 29% to 37% reduction in influenza transmission rates.
targetString: Mibeko bakonzi bazwaki ya kokanga biteyelo mpe kopekisa bato basangana esalaki ete taux ya bato oyo bazwaki grippe ekita na 29% ti 37%.

sourceString: Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: Bokangi ya biteyelo noki-noki na États-Unis, esalaki ete maladi mabe ya grippe H1N1 2009 emata mpenza te.

sourceString: Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.
targetString: Atako kokanga biteyelo esalisi mingi, bolukiluki moko na oyo etali kokanga biteyelo na Michigan emonaki ete “kokanga biteyelo na etuka na bango esalaki eloko te. Na ntango ya grippe ya bangulu ya 2009 ebimaki na Royaume-Uni, nkoma moko babengi "Kokanga biteyelo na ntango ya maladi mabe ya grippe” oyo babimisaki na Lancet Infectious Diseases, lisanga moko ya ba epidemiologiste balobaki kokanga biteyelo eza malamu mpo na kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te, mpe kozwa ntango ya kosala bolukiluki mpe kobimisa mangwele.

sourceString: Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.
targetString: Nsima ya koyekola maladi mabe ya gripe ata mpe grippe ya 1918, grippe ya 1957 mpe ya 1968, balobaki mpasi oyo kokanga biteyelo ememaki na nkita mpe na mosala, mingimingi mpo minganga na ba infirmer mingi baza basi, mpe katikati na bana na bango bakokisi nanu te 16.

sourceString: They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.
targetString: Batalaki mpe makasi ya bopalangani ya grippe na France ntango bana ya kelasi ya France bazalaki na congé mpe balobaki ete grippe ekitaki ntango bakangaki biteyelo mpe ekomaki lisusu makasi ntango bafungolaki yango.

sourceString: They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.
targetString: Balobaki ete ntango balakisi na Israele basalaki greve na ntango ya grippe ya 1999-2000, bavisite epai ya minganga mpe motango ya bato ya maladi ya mpema ekitaki na ndambo moko na kati ya mitano mpe ndambo mibale na kati ya mitano.

sourceString: For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Mpo na biteyelo mpe bisika babatelaka bana, Ba centre oyo ebundisaka maladi mpe ebatelaka bato na maladi wana elobaki bakanga yango na ntango mokuse mpo na kotya bopeto to kolongola mbindo soki moto moko azalaki na lopango ya eteyelo ata soki epanzani ndenge nini na mboka.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: Soki bokono ezopanzana mingi mpenza te na kati ya bato, bokoki kosalela mayele ya kopekisa bato bakutana na ndakisa kopekisa mibembo, mayangani, mpe makita mosusu ya minene na ndakisa education physique to korale na biteyelo to kolya na restaurant, ata mpe distance ezokabola babiro, kozelazela na ntango ya koya to ya kokende, koboya bavisite ezangi ntina, mpe kosalela babiro ya minganga ekeseni mpo na bana oyo bazali na bilembo ya grippe.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
targetString: Soki bokaboli ya bokono ezali makasi na esika bofandi, longola mayele ya kosenga bato bazala mosika na basusu, bokoki kokanisa kokanga biteyelo.

sourceString: On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 26 sanza ya yambo, Chine atyaki mibeko mpo na kobundisa maladi COVID-19 ata mpe kobongola date ya fete ya Printemps mpo na kokanga yango nzela epanzana te.

sourceString: Universities and schools around the country closed.
targetString: Bakangaki ba iniversite na biteyelo ya mboka wana.

sourceString: On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 23 sanza ya mibale, ministere ya santé ya Iran elobaki bakangi ba iniversite, biteyelo ya likolo na biteyelo na bingumba mpe bituka.

sourceString: On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 3 sanza ya misato, UNESCO abimisi motango ya liboso ya biteyelo oyo bakangaki na mokili mobimba mpe bana kelasi oyo kelasi ekatanaki.

sourceString: It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.
targetString: Balobaki ete mikili 13 babimisaki mibeko ya kokanga maladi nzela epanzana te na ndakisa kokanga biteyelo mpe ba iniversite mpo na ntango moke, yango epesaki mpasi na bana kelasi bamilio 290,5 na mokili mobimba.

sourceString: In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.
targetString: Yango wana, UNESCO esengaki mikili basalisa bana kelasi oyo bazwi mpasi mpe mabota na bango mpe basalisa bango na kozwa mateya na nzela ya baprograme ya boyekoli ya mosika.

sourceString: On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 4 sanza ya misato, guvernema ya Italie epesaki mobeka bakanga biteyelo mpe ba iniversite nyonso na Italie mpo bato 100 basi bakufaki.

sourceString: In doing so, Italy became one of 22 countries on three continents which had announced or implemented school closures.
targetString: Na kosalaka bongo, Italie ekomaki moko ya mikili 22 oyo elobaki ete bakanga biteyelo to bakokanga yango.

sourceString: On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 5 sanza ya misato, bayekoli mingi oyo bazwaki mokakatano mpo na mibeko ya lombangu bazwaki mpo na COVID-19 bazalaki na Chine, bayekoli bamilio 233 bazwaki mokakatano wana, na nsima na Japon motango na bango ezalaki bamilio 16,5 mpe Iran bamilio 14,5.

sourceString: By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 10 sanza ya misato, mwana kelasi moko na kati ya mitano na mokili mobimba “ezalaki kokende kelasi te mpo na COVID-19" ebongo moko na kati ya minei bazalaki kokende biteyelo ya minene te.

sourceString: On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 13 sanza ya misato, baguvernema ya mikili 49 balobaki to bakangaki biteyelo, kati na yango mikili 39 oyo ekangaki biteyelo na mboka mobimba mpe mikili 22 oyo ekangaki biteyelo oyo bango moko baponaki.

sourceString: By 16 March, this figure increased from 49 to 73 countries according to UNESCO.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 16 sanza ya misato, UNESCO alobaki ete motango wana elongwaki na 49 mpe ekomaki mikili 73.

sourceString: By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 19 sanza ya misato, bana ya kelasi 50% na mokili mobimba bazwaki mokakatano mpo na bokangi biteyelo, emonisi ete na mikili 102 bakangaki biteyelo ya mboka mobimba mpe mikili 11 bakangaki biteyelo ndambu; bana mpe bilenge bamilio 850 bazwaki mokakatano mpo na yango.

sourceString: By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 20 sanza ya misato, bayekoli koleka 70% na mokili mobimba bazwaki mokakatano mpo na bokangi wana; mikili 124 bakangaki biteyelo nyonso ya mboka na bango.

sourceString: On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 23 sanza ya misato, guvernema ya Nigeria ekangaki biteyelo nyonso, bazando mpe bakompani mpe baboti bapekisaki bana na bango na kobima libanda ya bandako.

sourceString: On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 26 sanza ya misato, biteyelo mpe ba iniverisite nyonso ya Nouvelle Zélande ekangamaki na mboka mobimba.

sourceString: The government has imposed a two-week holiday, allowing schools to transition to forms of distant teaching as soon as possible.
targetString: Guvernema epesaki bango congé ya bamposo mibale; epesaki biteyelo nzela ya kobanda kosalela lolenge ya koteya na mosika soki likoki ezali.

sourceString: Universities have closed for one week, but resumed with online teaching afterwards.
targetString: Bakangaki ba iniversite nyonso mpo na mposo moko, kasi ezongaka na nsima na koyekola na nzela ya internet.

sourceString: Other school services remain open, but teaching is restricted to distant learning.
targetString: Misala mosusu ya biteyelo ekobaki, kasi koteya esukaki kaka na nzela ya internet.

sourceString: By 27 March, nearly 90 percent of the world's student population was out of class.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 27 sanza ya misato, pene ya 90 pourcent ya bayekoli na mokili mobimba bazalaki kokende lisusu kelasi te.

sourceString: Regions with schools remaining open included Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, and some U.S. states.
targetString: Bituka oyo biteyelo ekangamaki te ezalaki Taïwan, Singapour, Australie, Swede, mpe bituka mosusu ya États-Unis.

sourceString: By 29 March, more than 1.5 billion children and other students were affected by nationwide school closures.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 29 sanza ya misato, bana mpe bayekoli mosusu pene ya 1,5 miliard bazwaki mokakatano na mokili mobimba mpo bakangaki biteyelo.

sourceString: Others were disrupted by localized closures.
targetString: Basusu bazwaki mokakatano mpo na bakangaki biteyelo moke.

sourceString: Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.
targetString: Kino na mokolo ya 6 sanza ya misato, biteyelo nyonso ya secondaire ya Turkmenistan ezalaki na congé.

sourceString: An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.
targetString: Ministre ya santé abimisaki mobeko moko mpo na kokanga maladi ya mpema epanzana te na kolanda etinda ya OMS mpo na coronavirisi.

sourceString: 10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates  473,933,356  learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.
targetString: Mikili 10 ekangaki biteyelo oyo baponaki, UNESCO elobi ete bayekoli 473 933 356 bakoki kozala na likama (maternelle kino na secondaire) mpe bayekoli 77 938 904 baza na likama eza baoyo ya nivo ya tertiaire.

sourceString: Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.
targetString: Likebisi: Mitango ekokani na motango ya bayekoli bakomisaki na maternelle, primaire, secondaire ya nse, mpe secondaire ya likolo [banivo SCED 0 kino na 3], mpe eteyelo ya tertiaire [banivo SCED 5 kino na 8] oyo bakoki kozala na mokakatano soki bakangaki biteyelo na mokili mobimba.

sourceString: Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.
targetString: Motango ya bayekoli bamikomisa na kotalela bansango ya sika ya institut de statstique UNESCO.

sourceString: School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.
targetString: Kokanga biteyelo mpo na maladi mabe ya COVID-19 esalisi na koyeba makambo mingi oyo ekangaka bato nzela bayekola, mpe komonisa polele makambo ya mpasi ya mbongo.

sourceString: As of March 12, more than 370 million children and youth are not attending school because of temporary or indefinite country wide school closures mandated by governments in an attempt to slow the spread of COVID-19.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 12 sanza ya misato, bana mpe bilenge koleka bamilio 370 bazalaki kokende te kelasi mpo bakangaki biteyelo mpo na ntango moke to mpo na ntango eyebani te na mokili na bango na kolanda mobeko baguvernema bazwaki mpo na kokanga COVID-19 nzela epanzana te.

sourceString: As of 29 March, nearly 90% of the world's learners were impacted by closures.Even when school closures are temporary, it carries high social and economic costs.
targetString: Na mokolo ya 29 sanza ya misato, pene ya bayekoli 90% na mokili mobimba bazalaki na mokakatano mpo na bokangi wana. Ata ntango bakangi yango mpo na ntango mokuse, ezalaki mpasi mingi na makambo ya bomoi mpe ya nkita.

sourceString: The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.
targetString: Bampasi na yango ekomelaka bato ya mikili mingi, kasi ezalaka mpasi mingi mpo na bana ya babola mpe mabota na bango mpo yango ekataka boyekoli, bana bazangaka bilei, bazangaka babateli mpe esengaka mabota oyo ezosala te babimisa mbongo.

sourceString: Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.
targetString: Baboti oyo basalaka bazangaki mpenza mosala soki biteyelo ekangami mpo esengaka babatela bana na bango, yango esalaka bazanga basalere mpe mosala esalemaka malamu te.

sourceString: Localised school closures place burdens on schools as parents and officials redirect children to schools that are open.
targetString: Kokanga biteyelo oyo baponi etyaka kilo mingi na mapeka ya baboti mpe bakonzi mpe bakomisa bana na biteyelo oyo ekangami te.

sourceString: Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.
targetString: Mbala mingi basi bazalaka motango monene ya bato oyo babatelaka bana mpe mbala mingi bakoki te kokende mosala mpo basengeli kobatela bana oyo biteyelo ekangami.

sourceString: This means that many medical professionals are not at the facilities where they are most needed during a health crisis.
targetString: Elimboli ete minganga mingi baza te na bisika na bango ya mosala esika oyo baza mpenza na mposo na bango mpo na maladi oyo.

sourceString: Lack of access to technology or fast, reliable internet access can prevent students in rural areas and from disadvantaged families.
targetString: Kozanga technologie to internet ya malamu ekoki kokanga bayekoli ya bamboka nzela mpe kozala mpasi mpo na mabota ya bobola.

sourceString: Lack of access to technology or good internet connectivity is an obstacle to continued learning, especially for students from disadvantaged families.
targetString: Kozanga technologie to internet ya malamu eza likama mpo na kokoba koyekola, mingimingi mpo na bayekoli oyo baza na mabota ya bobola.

sourceString: In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.
targetString: Mpo na kokanga biteyelo na ntina ya COVID-19, UNESCO alobi basalela baprograme ya koyekola na mosika mpe bafungola ba-application mpe bisika oyo biteyelo na balakisi bakoki kosalela mpo koteya na mosika mpe kosala ete bato mingi te bakata koyekola. Mpo na kosalisa mpo COVID-19 epanzana mingi, bakangi babiblioteke mosusu mpo na ntango moke.

sourceString: In the United States, numerous major cities announced public library closures, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York City, affecting 221 libraries.
targetString: Na États-Unis, bingumba mingi ya minene elobaki bakangi babiblioteke na ndakisa Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, mpe New York City; bakangi babiblioteke 221.

sourceString: For students without internet at home, this increases the difficulty of keeping up with distance learning.
targetString: Mpo na bayekoli bazangi internet na ndako, yango ezomatisa mokakatano ya kolanda koyekola na mosika.

sourceString: School closures puts a strain on parents and guardians to provide childcare and manage distance learning while children are out of school.
targetString: Kokanga biteyelo etya kilo mingi na baboti mpe babateli mpo babatela bana mpe kokoba koyekola na mosika ntango bana bazokende kelasi te.

sourceString: In the absence of alternative options, working parents often leave children alone when schools close and this can lead to risky behaviours, including increased influence of peer pressure and substance abuse.
targetString: Soki makoki mosusu eza te, mbala mingi baboti oyo basalaka batikaka bana bango moko ntango biteyelo ekangaka mpe yango ekoki kosala ete bana bakoma na bizaleli mabe, ata mpe baninga mabe mpe kosalela bilangwiseli.

sourceString: Many children worldwide rely on free or discounted meals at schools.
targetString: Bana mingi na mokili mobimba balyaka biloko ya ofele oyo bapesaka na biteyelo.

sourceString: When schools close, nutrition is compromised.Nutrition plays a critical role in cognitive development and academic performance for children.In Washington State, around 45% of the states 1.1 million students enrolled in traditional public and charter schools qualify for subsidised school meals.
targetString: Soki biteyelo ekangami, bana wana balyaka na mpasi. Kolya ezalaka ntina mingi na bokoli ya bana mpe mayele na bango na kelasi. Na etuka ya Washington, pene ya bato 45%, elingi koloba bayekoli 1,1 milio bamikotisa na bakelasi ya traditionnel mpe biteyelo mosusu mpo na kozwa mwa bilei.

sourceString: At least 520,000 students and their families may be affected by food insecurity as a result of school closures.School lunch programmes are the second-biggest anti-hunger initiative in the United States after food stamps.
targetString: Pene ya bayekoli 520 000 na mabota na bango bakoki kokoma na mokakatano y bilei mpo biteyelo ekangami. Baprograme ya kolya ya midi ya biteyelo eza mwango ya monene ya mibale na États-Unis oyo esalisaka na kobundisa nzala.

sourceString: Every year, nearly 30 million children rely on schools to provide free or low-cost meals including breakfast, lunch, snacks, and even dinner.In Alabama, where state-wide school closures as of 18 March have affected over 720,000 students, the state Superintendent announced that staff in schools disproportionately affected by poverty would create meal distribution networks to provide food for students who rely on school lunches.
targetString: Mbula nyonso, pene ya bamilio 30 ya bana balyaka mingimingi bilei ya ofele to ya ntalo moke oyo biteyelo epesaki mpo na ntongo, midi, mboka mpe butu. Na Alabama, esika kokanga biteyelo na etuka mobimba na mokolo ya 18 sanza ya misato epesi mokakatano na bayekoli koleka 720 000, mokengeli ya etuka alobaki ete bana oyo basalaka na biteyelo oyo baza na mokakatano makasi mpo na bobola bakosala bibongiseli mpo na kopesa bilei na bayekoli oyo bilei ya midi eutaka na biteyelo.

sourceString: School closures negatively impact student learning outcomes.
targetString: Kokangama ya biteyelo eza na bopusi mabe na résultat ya bana kelasi oyo yango ememeli mokakatano.

sourceString: Schooling provides essential learning and when schools close, children and youth are deprived opportunities for growth and development.
targetString: Biteyelo epesaka mateya ya ntina mpe soki ekangami, bana na bilenge bazangaka mabaku ya kokola malamu.

sourceString: The disadvantages are disproportionate for under-privileged learners who tend to have fewer educational opportunities beyond school.Student drop-out rates tend to increase as an effect of school closures due to the challenge of ensuring all students return to school once school closures ends.
targetString: Makama eza mingi mpo na bayekoli oyo baza na mpasi, oyo bazalaka na mabaku mingi te ya kotanga nsima ya eteyelo. Kokangama ya biteyelo esalaka ete motango ya bana balingi kelasi ekita mpo na bampasi ya kosalisa bana nyonso bazonga na kelasi soki efungwami lisusu.

sourceString: This is especially true of protracted closures.Schools are hubs of social activity and human interaction.
targetString: Eza soli mingimingi mpo na bokangi ya ntango molai. Biteyelo eza bisika ya makambo ya bomoi mpe ya bokutani na bato mosusu.

sourceString: When schools are closed, many children and youth miss out of on social contact that is essential to learning and development.When schools close parents are often asked to facilitate the learning of children at home and can struggle to perform this task.
targetString: Soki biteyelo ekangami, bana mpe bilenge mingi bazangaka libaku ya kokutana na bato mosusu oyo eza ntina mpo na mayele na bango ya koyekola mpe bokoli na bango. Soki biteyelo ekangami mbala mingi basengaki baboti basalisa na koteya bana na ndako kasi ezalaka mpasi mpo basala yango.

sourceString: This is especially true for parents with limited education and resources.
targetString: Eza solo mingimingi mpo na baboti oyo batanga mingi te mpe baza na bozwi mingi te.

sourceString: Potential impacts of school closures and reliance on distance learning are not addressed in federal acts of legislation at this time.
targetString: Bampasi ya kokangama ya biteyelo mpe ya koyekola na mosika, mibeko ya leta elobeli yango te kino sikoyo.

sourceString: Formal education — as opposed to informal education or non-formal education — tends to refer to schools, colleges, universities and training institutions.
targetString: Boyekoli ya formel — soki tokesenisi yango na boyekoli ya informel to oyo eza formel te — mbala mingi ezali biteyelo, ba collège, ba iniversite mpe bisika bateyaka bato.

sourceString: A 1974 report by the World Bank defined formal education as the following:Formal education: the hierarchically structured, chronologically graded ‘education system', running from primary school through the university and including, in addition to general academic studies, a variety of specialised programmes and institutions for full-time technical and professional training.The majority of data collected on the number of students and learners impacted by COVID-19 has been calculated based on the closure of formal education systems.
targetString: Na 1974 rapore ya Work Bank elobaki ete boyekoli formel ezali: Boyekoli formel: esika ebongisami malamu, bakelasi oyo ‘bamataka,' banda na primaire kino na iniversite mpe, longola boyekoli ya ba academie, eza na baprograme mingi ya ntina oyo epesaka mateya ya technique mpe ya professionnel. Bansango ya bana kelasi mpe ya bayekoli mingi oyo tozwi, baoyo bakutani na mokakatano mpo na COVID-19, to calculer yango na kotala bokangami ya biteyelo ya formel.

sourceString: The UNESCO Institute for Statistics provides figures on students impacted by COVID-19 corresponding to the number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8].
targetString: Institut de stastique UNESCO epesi motango ya bayekoli oyo bakutani na mokakatano mpo na COVID-19 na kolanda motango ya bayekoli oyo bakomisa bankombo na maternelle, primaire, secondaire ya nse, mpe secondaire ya likolo [banivo SCED 0 kino na 3], mpe eteyelo ya tertiaire [banivo SCED 5 kino na 8].

sourceString: Early childhood educational programmes are usually designed for children below the age of 3 and may refer to preschools, nursery schools, kindergartens, and some day care programmes.
targetString: Biteyelo ya ebandeli mpo na bana, basala yango mingi mpo na bana oyo bakokisi nanu te mibu 3 te mpe bakoki kobenga yango maternelle, gardienne mpe baprograme mosusu ya kobatela bana.

sourceString: While many primary and secondary schools have closed around the world due to COVID-19, measures impacting early childhood educational programmes have varied.
targetString: Ata biteyelo mingi ya primaire mpe ya secondaire ekangami na mokili mobimba mpo na COVID-19, mibeko oyo etye bipekiseli na baprograme ya bana mike ekeseni.

sourceString: In some countries and territories, preschools and day cares are considered necessary services and have not closed in tandem with broader school closure measures.In the United States, the Washington State Department of Children, Youth, and Families encouraged child care and early learning centres to stay open.
targetString: Na mikili mpe bisika mosusu, biteyelo ya maternelle mpe ya kobatela bana bamonaka yango misala ya ntina mpe bakangi yango te mpo na mibeko ya kokanga bakelasi oyo bazwi. Na États-Unis, ministere ya bana, bilenge mpe mabota ya etuka ya Washington, elobaki ete bakanga te bisika ya kobatela bana mpe bacentre ya koyekola.

sourceString: Some school districts may offer alternative child care options, prioritising the children of first responders and healthcare workers.
targetString: Biteyelo mosusu ya etuka ekoki kopesa makanisi mosusu mpo na libateli ya bana, kotya na esika ya liboso bana ya minganga mpe ba infirmier.

sourceString: The governor of Maryland mandated that specific child care services remain open for the children of emergency personnel while Washington State and California have left it to the discretion of care providers.
targetString: Guverneur ya Maryland alobaki ete misala ya kobatela bana esengeli kokoba mpo na bana ya bato oyo bazosalisa, kasi etuka ya Washington mpe ya Californie, minganga na ba infirmier bazwa ekateli bango moko.

sourceString: California Governor Gavin Newsom explained his state's position, saying “We need our child care facilities, our daycare centers, to operate to absorb the impact of these school closures.”
targetString: Guverneur ya Californie Gavin Newsom alimbolaki ekateli na ye, alobaki “Toza na mposa ya bisika na biso ya kobatela bana, ba centre ya kobatela bana, esala mpo bopusi ya kokanga biteyelo eza mingi te.”

sourceString: Colorado has encouraged the development of "tool kits" for parents to use at home to emulate the lessons children would have received in their early learning programmes.In Japan, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe closed all schools throughout the country until April 8, however, children's daycare facilities were excluded.
targetString: Colorado elendisaki kosala “bisaleli” mpo baboti baselela yango na ndako mpo na komekola mateya oyo balingaki kozwa na baprograme ya koyekola na maternelle. Na Japon, premier ministre Shinzo Abe akangaki biteyelo nyonso na mboka mobimba kino na mokolo ya 8 sanza ya minei, kasi akangaki te bisika babatelaka bana.

sourceString: In early March, five adults associated with a nursing facility for preschool children in Kobe tested positive for coronavirus.
targetString: Na ebandeli ya sanza ya misato, mikolo mitano oyo basalaka na bisika oyo babatelaka bana ya maternelle na Kobe, bakangaki bango maladi ya coronavirisi.

sourceString: After testing over one hundred children at the facility, a preschool student was found to be carrying the virus.
targetString: Nsima ya kosalisa bana nkama moko ya esika wana ekzame, bazwaki mwana moko ya maternelle maladi wana.

sourceString: Primary or elementary education typically consists of the first four to seven years of formal education.
targetString: Biteyelo ya primaire to ya elementaire ezali kelasi ya liboso kino ya minei na bakelasi nsambo ya biteyelo ya formel.

sourceString: The International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) canceled the examinations for its Diploma Programme and Career-related Programme candidates scheduled between 30 April and 22 May 2020, reportedly affecting more than 200,000 students worldwide.
targetString: International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) elobaki bakosala te ba-ekzame mpo na programe na yango ya kozwa maplome mpe ya kosalisa na kozwa misala oyo esengelaki kosalema kati na mokolo ya 30 sanza ya minei kino na mokolo ya 22 sanza ya mitano 2020, epesi mokakatano na bayekoli kolela 200 000 na mokili mobimba.

sourceString: The IBO stated that it would award candidates their diplomas or certificates based on "their coursework" and "the established assessment expertise, rigor, and quality control already built into the programme."
targetString: IBO alobaki ete ekopesa bakandida maplome na bango to ba certificat na kotalela “banoti na bango ya kelasi” mpe “botaleli ya mayele, makasi, qualité oyo bazalaki na yango deja na programe.”

sourceString: Tertiary education, also known as higher education, refers to the non-compulsory educational levels that follow completion of secondary school or high school.
targetString: Biteyelo ya tertiaire, oyo eyebani neti biteyelo ya likolo, eza biteyelo ya obligatoire te oyo basalaka nsima ya kosilisa eteyelo ya secondaire to ya likolo.

sourceString: Tertiary education is normally taken to include undergraduate and postgraduate education, as well as vocational education and training.
targetString: Biteyelo ya tertiaire etalelaka mpe cycle ya liboso mpe cycle ya misato, ata mpe mateya mpe formation professionnel.

sourceString: Individuals who complete tertiary education generally receive certificates, diplomas, or academic degrees.
targetString: Mbala mingi bato oyo basilisi eteyelo ya tertiaire bazwaka certificat, diplome to degree académique.

sourceString: Undergraduate education is education conducted after secondary education and prior to post-graduate education, for which the learner is typically awarded a bachelor's degree.
targetString: Eteyelo ya cycle ya liboso eza mateya oyo bazwaka nsima ya eteyelo ya secondiare mpe ya liboso ya cycle ya misato, mpo na bayekoli bapesaka bango diplome ya licence.

sourceString: Students enrolled in higher education programmes at colleges, universities, and community colleges are often refereed to in countries such as United States as "college students."The closure of colleges and universities has widespread implications for students, faculty, administrators, and the institutions themselves.
targetString: Bana ya kelasi oyo bakomisami na baprograme ya biteyelo ya likolo ya ba collège, iniversite, mpe ba collège mosusu, babengaka bango mbala mingi na mikili neti États-Unis “bayekoli ya collège.” Bokangami ya ba collège mpe ba iniversite eza na bopusi makasi mpo na bayekoli, faculté, bakonzi, mpe bibongiseli yango moko.

sourceString: Colleges and universities across the United States have been called upon to issue refunds to students for the cost of tuition and room and board.
targetString: Ba collège mpe ba iniversite na États-Unis bazolobela likambo ya kosenga mosolo na bana kelasi mpo na mbongo ya kelasi, bandako mpe bateyi.

sourceString: In the United States of America, Colleges and universities operate as "mini-cities" which generate significant revenue for cities, states, and regions.
targetString: Na États-Unis ya Amerika, ba collège na ba iniversite esalaka neti “bingumba ya mike” oyo ememelaka bingumba, bituka mpe bamboka mbongo mingi.

sourceString: For example, Princeton University contributed $1.58 billion USD to the New Jersey economy and students spent about $60 million in off-campus spending.

sourceString: College and university closures have a domino effect on economies with far-reaching implications.According to Linda Bilmes of the Harvard Kennedy School, "local hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, car rental agencies and other local businesses obtain a significant share of annual revenue from graduation week and college reunions...

sourceString: these communities will suffer a lot of economic damage if the colleges remain closed at that time."Small towns which rely on college students to support the local economy and provide labour to local businesses are especially impacted by school closures and the exodus of students from campus.

sourceString: In Ithaca, New York, Cornell University students spent at least $4 million a week in Tompkins county.
